Acro_ID=14&OldAcro_ID=14&Acronym=ACS&OldAcronym=ACS&Definition=Afloat+Correlation+System%2FAmphibious+Command+Ship&OldDefinition=Afloat+Correlation+System%2FAmphibious+Command+Ship&Meaning=testing+put2&OldMeaning=testing+put2&Acro_Date=11%2F2%2F2001+12%3A36%3A43+PM&OldAcro_Date=11%2F2%2F2001+12%3A36%3A43+PM
>
> Correct?

Yep

>
> If so, IIS5.1 + Classic ASP will parse the contents of the PUT with
> content type of application/x-www-form-urlencoded into the
> Request.form collection happily for you.

Good news! That's the evidence nic is looking for.

> If you're looking for
> something that works like what you think it should.  (Not that I found
> a web browser that would let me do <form method='PUT'
> action='EditAcro.asp'> and not convert it into a 'GET'.  (AJAX to the
> rescue to test.)
>

You know, it's probably just as well HTML didn't specify form PUT. You
just know that webapps everywhere would have one single "putdata.asp"
resource that simply acts like a POST i.e. a GET on the resource
giving you a form, not what you just PUT there....


Hugh
